title: 114_hr1428
content: The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" allows covered persons from designated countries to bring civil actions against agencies for privacy violations, with remedies similar to those under the Privacy Act. The Act specifies the limitations and exemptions for such actions. The exclusive remedies available to covered persons under this section are outlined, with the same rights and limitations as under the Privacy Act when pursuing civil actions. The Attorney General, with the concurrence of other officials, may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" for this purpose. The Attorney General may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it has privacy protections for information shared to prevent criminal offenses or has effectively shared information with the US for this purpose. The Attorney General may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it allows the transfer of personal data for commercial purposes to the United States and does not impede US national security interests. The designation can be removed with the concurrence of the Secretary of State. The Attorney General can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if it fails to comply with certain requirements, such as not meeting the agreement terms, failing to meet certification requirements, or impeding the transfer of information to the United States. The Attorney General determines designated Federal agencies or components for information exchange with covered countries. The Attorney General designates Federal agencies or components for information exchange with covered countries, with determinations published in the Federal Register and not subject to review. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over claims under this section. Definitions in the Act include the term "agency." The term "agency" in this context refers to its definition in section 552(f) of title 5, United States Code. A "covered country" is a country or regional economic organization designated under subsection (d). A "covered person" is a non-individual citizen of a covered country. A "covered record" for a covered person is similar to a record under section 552a of title 5, once transferred by a public authority or private entity in a covered country. The Act defines terms such as "covered country," "designated Federal agency," and "individual." It also clarifies that privileges are preserved and classified information is not required to be disclosed. The Act will take effect 90 days after enactment.
